channel.title: Broadband on Voyager Internet Ltd.
channel.description: Recent content in Broadband on Voyager Internet Ltd.

item.title: What is the best broadband for gaming in NZ?
item.description: The best type of broadband for gamers is fibre, due to it’s very low ping, low jitter, and high data transfer rate.

item.title: What is the best broadband for working from home?
item.description: The best broadband to get which enables you to work from home effectively is a fast, stable connection, with unlimited data.

item.title: Voyager Static IP Address
item.description: A static IP address is available on request for Voyager home broadband connections, and is included by default free of charge with all Voyager business broadband connections.

item.title: What should I do if I want to move my Fibre ONT?
item.description: If you’re wanting to shift your Fibre ONT box to a different location inside your home, this can usually be achieved by speaking with your fibre broadband provider.

item.title: Is Fibre Max worth it?
item.description: If your household is made up of multiple people streaming HD/4K content and gaming, Fibre Max is worth going for.

item.title: How to switch broadband provider in NZ?
item.description: The process for switching broadband provider is quite straight forward.

item.title: Fibre vs Wireless Broadband - which is better in NZ?
item.description: Fibre is the clear winner when it comes to dependability of connection, lower ping times, lower jitter, and speed of internet connectivity available.

item.title: Does Fibre broadband work in a power outage?
item.description: Fibre broadband requires that your ONT and router are both powered on to function, so it will not work in a power outage.

item.title: What is the fibre broadband installation process in New Zealand?
item.description: The installation process for fibre depends primarily on your property type.

item.title: What if I'm not happy with the quality of my Fibre installation?
item.description: If you’re unhappy with the quality of your fibre install, or the condition in which your property has been left, you’re able to raise this with your broadband provider.

item.title: What is a Fibre ONT?
item.description: An ONT (or Optical Network Terminal) is a small device that is attached to the wall of your home or office, which allows you to get connected to Fibre Broadband.

item.title: What are the different fibre broadband install methods?
item.description: Fibre can be installed via several different methods, including surface-mounted (along fence for example), underground ducting, aerial cable overhead, or buried cable.

item.title: How much does home fibre broadband installation cost in NZ?
item.description: A standard fibre installation to a residential home doesn’t usually cost anything – although it’s worth noting that some internet providers do charge a setup fee.

item.title: How long does it take to get fibre broadband installed?
item.description: Getting Fibre installed in New Zealand is now a very quick process for most homes and businesses.

item.title: Who do I need consent from to get Fibre installed?
item.description: The fibre broadband installation consent process varies depending on your property type, who owns it, and who will be impacted by the work done.

item.title: How can I get more than one Fibre Broadband connection in my house?
item.description: There are a two options for getting multiple fibre broadband connections at your place, which are:

item.title: When can I get fibre broadband at my property?
item.description: While Ultra-Fast Broadband was originally made available in only a select few cities around New Zealand, the nationwide rollout has progressed ahead of schedule to now cover most Kiwi households and businesses.

item.title: What is Fibre Broadband (UFB)?
item.description: Also known as Ultra-Fast Broadband (UFB), Fibre Broadband is New Zealand’s nationwide modern internet infrastructure – which is systematically replacing our countries old copper phoneline based internet connectivity, which includes ADSL and VDSL.

item.title: Fibre (UFB) vs VDSL vs ADSL
item.description: When it comes to internet in New Zealand, things have come a long way!

item.title: VDSL Jackpoint FAQ
item.description: If you’ve got a VDSL broadband connection installed at your property, you might be wondering what cable to use to connect your modem/router to the VDSL jackpoint.

item.title: Broadband Data Usage in New Zealand Homes
item.description: Every year New Zealanders are using more and more monthly broadband data, and with all our devices and streaming services that’s not too surprising.

item.title: Moving house? Get broadband and phone sorted easily!
item.description: Ah yes, moving house. Everyone’s favourite activity. You’ve made the decision on where you’re moving, having picked out your new home to rent or to buy - and now comes the hard part, moving all your stuff!

item.title: What's the difference between WiFi and broadband?
item.description: Essentially WiFi is a wireless connection in your house or business, that connects your phone or computer to your modem/router, while Broadband is the actual internet connection that your modem/router uses to send and receive data from your house to the wider world.

item.title: Can I get internet without a landline?
item.description: Yes you can get broadband internet in New Zealand without a landline (a copper phone line).

item.title: What internet speed do I need for gaming?
item.description: The absolute minimum internet speed as recommended by Xbox and Playstation is 3Mbps download and between 0.

item.title: Why is my internet so slow?
item.description: The most common reasons that can cause slow internet speeds are:

item.title: How to change your WIFI name
item.description: When you get your modem / router it will be pre-configured with a WIFI name (SSID) that is what will show up in the list of available WIFI access points on your wireless devices.

item.title: What is a good internet speed in NZ? (and how to improve it!)
item.description: High speed broadband is now the norm across New Zealand, thanks largely to widespread adoption of the Fibre broadband (UFB) that has been rolled out all over the country.

item.title: Compare Broadband deals and speeds in NZ (what to look for!)
item.description: The state of internet in New Zealand has never been better.

item.title: Voyager credited for playing significant role in success of independent information company
item.description: Independent information company Multimedia Investments Ltd (MIL) credits Voyager for playing a significant role in its success

item.title: Gaming lounge powers up business with Voyager fibre broadband
item.description: Kiwi business owner Callum Jennings is encouraging more New Zealand businesses to make the switch to fibre broadband after experiencing a “monumental increase in speed, significantly lower latency, and greater connection stability” at his own gaming lounge in Auckland.

item.title: Voyager completes upgrade of core network
item.description: Voyager Internet has recently completed a 100 Gigabit upgrade of its core data network.

item.title: Why you’re better off buying boutique broadband
item.description: When it comes to consumer reviews, telco companies usually get a pretty bad rap.
